	Like I said, I completely understand that you and even the

Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Patents and suchlike...
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225; y=Hvu6pLV_7arxMitPVB4uE1AD5LxtVIeM6A2J5qQpSufxAFy6Jg
X-Yahoo-Profile: ian_badcoe

Hi Ken,

	Like I said, I completely understand that you and even the 
university have reasons, even pressing reasons, to raise the 
patent.  As you say, it can be necessary just to protect against 
other people doing it.

	I think my problem might be one of the difference between broad 
concepts and fine details.

	e.g. the broad concept of continuous NEAT is to my mind obvious.  In 
fact, I think about the third thing I thought when I first read your 
paper (after "now how does this work?" and "that is clever!") was "if 
I did this, I would do it continuously".

	And many of the ideas involved in doing that, are very obvious and 
also not specific to NEAT:

- replacing one unfit individual at a time
- picking fit parents
- minimum life if required

	So I would be very uncomfortable if the patent tried to cover any of 
these basic concepts.

	OTOH, the devil is in the details, and so also is the hard work and 
the place where a person's talents most show.  So I would never wish 
to stop you protecting your investment in that.

--

	The other side of this is that not everything discussed is clearly 
property of one or other individual....

	e.g. arbitrary labels, I invented those!  I distinctly remember it 
was about 10 years ago and I wanted them for GP at the time....

	Equally, I completely believe Colin used a version of them in one of 
his old projects...

	And that you (Ken) came up with them in the context you were 
describing yesterday...

	So, until about 2 months ago all three of us genuinely believed we 
had a novel, unique and useful invention there.  And either one of us 
might have patented it, to the horror of the others....

	...but that's to do with the nature of patent and nothing we can control :)

--

	Anyway, you have clarified the situation a lot an reassured me 
somewhat, but can you briefly tell us what is and isn't covered by the patent?

	Is this patent only in the US?

	Ian

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
